This page requires frames. Click here for the non-frames version.
Requests to the main site will be redirected to this journal. This may be useful if the site is hosting only a single journal, for example.
You must enter a minimum password length of at least 4 characters.
Are you sure you want to expire all user sessions? All users who are currently logged into the system will be forced to log in again (yourself included).
Are you sure you want to clear the cache of compiled templates?
This will be the default language for the site and any hosted journals.

Select all locales to support on the site. The selected locales will be available for use by all journals hosted on the site, and also appear in a language select menu to appear on each site page (which can be overridden on journal-specific pages). If multiple locales are not selected, the language toggle menu will not appear and extended language settings will not be available to journals.
In registering people (editors, reviewers, copyeditors, etc.), working languages should be included in their User Profiles for the benefit of journal editors.
Are you sure you want to reload this locale? This will wipe out any existing locale-specific data like customized email templates.
Are you sure you want to uninstall this locale? This may affect any hosted journals currently using the locale.

Select any additional locales to install support for in this system. Locales must be installed before they can be used by hosted journals. See the OJS documentation for information on adding support for new languages.
No additional locales are available for installation.
Basic operating system and server software versions. Click on Extended PHP Information to view extended details of this server's PHP configuration.

Use this form to modify your system configuration (the config.inc.php file). Click "Save" to save your new configuration, or "Display" to simply display the updated configuration file and not modify your existing configuration.

Warning: Modifying these settings can potentially leave your site in an inaccessible state (requiring your configuration file to be manually fixed). It is strongly recommended that you do not make any changes unless you know exactly what you are doing.
The configuration file <tt>config.inc.php</tt> does not exist or is not readable.
The configuration file <tt>config.inc.php</tt> does not exist or is not readable.

NOTE!

The system could not automatically overwrite the configuration file. To apply your configuration changes you must open config.inc.php in a suitable text editor and replace its contents with the contents of the text field below.

The contents of your updated configuration are displayed below. To apply the configuration changes you must open <tt>config.inc.php</tt> in a suitable text editor and replace its contents with the contents of the text field below.

Your configuration file has been successfully updated. Please note that if your site no longer functions correctly you may need to manually fix your configuration by editing <tt>config.inc.php</tt> directly.
Are you sure you want to permanently delete this journal?
You will automatically be enrolled as the manager of this journal. After creating a new journal, enter it as a manager to continue with its setup and user enrollment.
The path can contain only alphanumeric characters, underscores, and hyphens, and must begin and end with an alphanumeric character.
The selected path is already in use by another journal.
Enable this journal to appear publicly on the site
View files associated with hosted journals.
Five Steps to a Journal Website
Your journal setup has been updated.

The ISSN (International Standard Serial Number) is an eight-digit number which identifies periodical publications as such, including electronic serials. It is managed by a world wide network of National Centres coordinated by an International Centre based in Paris, backed by Unesco and the French Government. A number can be obtained from the ISSN Website. This can be done at any point in operating the journal.
The journal's physical location and mailing address.

OJS comes with an Article Section and an optional Book/Media Review Section. These can be renamed and others added, with indexing, peer-reviewing and other options selected for each of them. Once a section is created, its options selected, then assign one or more editors to manage it, and ask them to write a policy statement for it.
  • Go to Section Management to edit features and enter policies for existing sections, as well as create additional sections for the journal.
  • Go to Editor Assignment to designate editors for the sections. This can be done at any point in operating the journal.
An editorial/review board will be used by the journal.

Journals have Editorial Boards to oversee the editorial direction of the journal and participate in the appoint of editors, as well as give the journal some standing in the field. Review Boards play a similar role, as well as taking the lead in the peer review process. These Board members will not have access to the journal's administrative system, but will be added to the list of those available to do peer reviews.
  • Go to Board Members and add Editorial Board and/or Review Board members. This can be done at any point in operating the journal.

This position, which can be treated as a principal editorship, managing editorship, or administrative staff position, will be listed on the homepage of the journal under Contact, along with the Technical Support Contact. The designation of Managing Editor the place in the Editors area of the Journal Administration.

This person will be listed on the journal's Contact page for the use of editors, authors, reviewers. As this journal system requires very little technical support, this should be seen as a very part-time assignment. There will be occasions when authors and reviewers have difficulties with the instructions or the file formats (.doc or .rtf), and the journal's technical support should be prepared to respond to such queries, as well as to advise the editors about HTML and PDF basics, and to ensure that the journal is regularly backed up on the server. The Technical Support person should, as should the principal contact and other editors, work through the system from author submission to Table of Contents with their own dummy article -- to understand how the system works -- after which point the article can be removed from the publishing process, archived, and deleted.

The name of the organization (e.g., scholarly association, university department, cooperative, etc.) sponsoring the journal will appear in About the Journal and may be accompanied by a note of acknowledgement. The first organization entered will be designated as the journal's publisher.
Additional agencies or organizations that provide financial or in-kind support for the journal will appear in About the Journal and may be accompanied by a note of acknowledgement.
To assist search engines in finding this journal, provide a brief description and select keywords.
Custom HTML header tags to be inserted in the header of every page (e.g., META tags).
If using HTML in Setup text boxes (for font size, bold, color, etc.), note that "returns" in the text are automatically treated as <tt><br></tt>.

Outline the journal's peer review policy and processes for readers and authors (in About the Journal), including the number of reviewers used in reviewing an submission, criteria by which reviewers are asked to judge submissions, typical time taken, and the principles for recruiting reviewers.
The typical period of time allowed for reviews
Can be modified during the editorial process
Automated reminders will be sent to reviewer (editor can also email reviewer)
Wording of these emails can be edited in Emails, Journal Management
If reviewer has not accepted/declined invitation to review, send
If reviewer has not submitted a recommendation, send
days after due date for review
Editors will be able to rate reviewers on a five-point scale after each review
Reviewers will only be allowed access to the submission file after agreeing to review it

The Review Guidelines provide reviewers with criteria for judging a submission's suitability for publication in the journal, as well as any special instructions for preparing an effective and helpful review.

OJS supports two models for managing the review process. The Standard Review Process is recommended, as both following standard practice and ensuring a complete review history for each submission, while taking advantage of automatic reminder notification and standard recommendations (Accept; Accept with revisions; Resubmit for review; Submit elsewhere; Decline; See comments).

Reviewers selected by Editors are emailed an invitation to review by email, along with the title and abstract, as well as username/password for the journal site. They log into journal Web site to agree to review and to view and download submissions. They submit their comments and select a recommendation on the Web site.

Reviewers selected by Editors will receive submissions, as email attachments, along with the invitation to review. They email their willingness to review, and later send their comments and recommendation to the editor by email, who will record these on the journal Web site to create a record for review process.

To create or modify sections for the journal (e.g., Articles, Book Reviews, etc.), go to Section Management.

Authors on submitting items to the journal will designate...
The journal section for which the item will be considered.
The journal editor who will see it through the editorial process.
(If sections are not added and the Book/Media Review section is not activated, then items are submitted to the Articles section by default.)
This statement will appear in About the Journal, as well as on the Author Submission and Notification sign-up pages. Below is a recommended privacy policy, which can be revised at any point.

The Public Knowledge Project has designed OJS to support "open access" journals, which are free to read, for reasons that are spelled out in a number of the papers available at the PKP website. If this is to be an open access journal, it should include a statement to this effect, along the lines suggested below (which can be edited). An "Open Access Research" logo will appear on the homepage. OJS can be modified to work with commercial journal systems.
Add Item to Appear in "About the Journal"
The number of reviewers per submission is required.
OJS provides a number of security-related options that can be used to restrict to the journal's contents, and maintain additional information about submissions for auditing purposes.
Allow users to register with the journal site as:
Disable user registration. Users will have to be manually created by a journal manager.
Unregistered users can view the journal site.
Users must sign in to view the journal site.
Unregistered users can view the full text of published articles.
Users must sign in to view the full text of published articles.
Enable submission event logging, which maintains a log of all actions on a submission (accessible via each submission's "History" page).
Enable submission email logging, which maintains a log of all emails sent out related to a submission (accessible via each submission's "History" page).

Specify bibliographic and formatting standards for the journal (e.g., Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association, 5th Edition, 2001) and/or provide examples of the common citation formats. Identify appropriate Supplementary Files (e.g., data-sets, research instruments, etc.) that authors are encouraged to upload in addition to their submission to extend the value and understanding of their work.

This format is only used with "Capture cite" on the Research Support Tool that accompanies each article (see 4.5). The journal can otherwise establish its own bibliographic standards, as outlined in its Author Guidelines.

The copyright notice will appear in About the Journal and Online Submission pages, as well as included at the end of each article. Below is a recommended notice, consistent with open access publishing, which can be altered by the editors.
For Authors to Index Their Work

OJS adheres to the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting, which is the emerging standard for providing well-indexed access to electronic research resources. This enables accurate searching of the metadata or indexing information across all OAI databases. The authors will use a template to assist them in providing metadata for their submission. Editors should select metadata elements that will improve the indexing of the journal, and provide authors with examples to guide them, using a semi-colon (e.g., "term1; term2") to separate terms.
Useful when journal crosses disciplinary boundaries and/or authors submit multidisciplinary items.
Provide examples of relevant academic disciplines for this journal
(E.g., History; Education; Sociology; Psychology; Cultural Studies; Law)

Journal will use a subject classification system available on the Web.
Title of classification system
(E.g., Mathematics Subject Classification; Library of Congress Classification)
Provide examples of keywords or topics as a guide for authors
(E.g., Photosynthesis; Black Holes; Four-Color Map Problem; Bayesian Theory)
Refers to geo-spatial location, chronological or historical coverage, and/or characteristics of research sample.
Provide examples of relevant geo-spatial or geographical terms for this field
(E.g., Iberian Peninsula; Stratosphere; Boreal Forest; etc.)
Provide examples of relevant chronological or historical terms for this field
(E.g., European Renaissance; Jurassic Period; Third Trimester; etc.)
Provide examples of research sample characteristics for this field
Provide examples of relevant research types, methods, and approaches for this field
(E.g., Historical Inquiry; Quasi-Experimental; Literary Analysis; Survey/Interview)

To have the contents of this journal indexed within a globally distributed system of research databases, register your journal's URL with the Public Knowledge Project metadata harvester. This tool collects the metadata from each indexed item in this journal, enabling accurate and collective searching among the research sites that adhere to the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting.

Click here and enter {$siteUrl} under Site URL, and {$oaiUrl} under Base URL for OAI Archive.

Journal items can be published collectively as a group when the Table of Contents is complete, or items can be published individually, by adding them to the "current" Table of Contents when they are ready. Either way, a format needs to be selected for identifying a published item:
As part of an issue, with volume, number, and year designated
As part of a volume alone, by volume and year designated.
None of the above, title only.
Depending on the format selected, identify the issue, volume, and/or year of the first issue to be published with OJS:

Steps: Submission Queue > Submission Review > Submission Editing > Scheduling Queue > Table of Contents.

Select a model for handling these aspects of the editorial process. (To designate a Managing Editor and Section Editors, go to Editors in Journal Administration.)
One or more editors handle the basic steps without designated roles.
Managing Editor handles Submission Queue, Scheduling Queue, and Table of Contents, while Section Editors handle Submission Review and Submission Editing.
Managing Editor handles Submission Queue, Submission Editing, Scheduling Queue, and Table of Contents, while the Section Editors handle Submission Review.
Items are copyedited by designated copyeditors (entered in Copyeditors, Journal Administration), or the copyediting can be left to the editor.
Copyeditors will be used by the journal.

Copyedit Instructions will be made available to both copyeditors, authors, and editors in the Submission Editing stage. Below is a default set of instructions in HTML, which can be modified or replaced by the editor at any point (in HTML or plain text).

After copyediting, the galleys are prepared in the appropriate file formats for publication (i.e., HTML, PDF, and/or PS) by a designated Layout Editor (identified as such in Editors, Journal Administration) or by the editor seeing the item through Submission Editing.
Layout editors will be used by the journal.
Items are proofread by designated Proofreaders (entered in Proofreaders, Journal Administration) and the author, or the proofing can be left to the editor and the author.
Proofreaders will be used by the journal.

Proofing Instructions will be made available to proofreader, authors, and editors in the Submission Editing stage. Below is a default set of instructions in HTML, which can be modified or replaced by the editor at any point (in HTML or plain text).
Unique Identifier: Articles and issues can be tagged with an identification number, employing a registration system such as the Digital Object Identifier System (DOI).
ID numbers will be used to identify issues.
ID numbers will be used to identify published items.
Page numbers for each published item will be included in the Table of Contents of this journal (e.g., pp. 13-26).

Title text or graphic version of the journal's title (saved as a .gif, .jpeg, or .png file), as well as a journal logo image, can be used on the journal's homepage, rather than relying on the title generated by OJS.
Add or remove navigation bar items.

Title text or graphic version of the journal's title (saved as a .gif, .jpeg, or .png file), as well as a journal logo image, can also appear (perhaps in a smaller version) at the top of each journal page (known as the header).
Alternately, instead of title and logo, an HTML version of the header can be inserted into the text box below. Leave textbox blank if not required.

This is the footer of your journal. To change or update the footer, paste the HTML code in the textbox below. Examples could be another navigation bar, a counter, etc. This footer will appear on every page.
By default journals and the site use the default.css style sheet. Overide default style rules by uploading a journal specific .css style sheet.

By default, the homepage consists of navigation links. Additional homepage content can be appended by using one or all of the following options, which will appear in the order shown. Also, a homepage, based perhaps on the journal's previous design or a new design, can be created and inserted into the system by someone skilled in HTML coding.

Add a brief 20-25 word description in text/HTML which will appear just below the navigation links. Add an image or graphic file to the middle of the page. Homepage image Additional Content Add the following content, using text/HTML, which will appear below homepage image, if one is uploaded. Add or remove navigation bar items. The label value is a literal string (e.g., "Journal Setup") rather than a localization message key (e.g., "manager.setup") URL is an absolute URL (e.g., "http://www.example.com") rather than a path relative to the site (e.g., "/manager/setup") Subscription support allows the full-text of all or selected articles in an issue to be restricted to a specified set of users, with the option for a limited period of time. Subscriptions Enable Subscriptions Add the table of contents for the current issue (if publishing by issue). OJS can be made available to users in any of several supported languages. As well, OJS can operate as a partially multilingual system, providing users with an ability to toggle between languages on each page, and allowing certain data to be entered in up to two additional languages.

If a language supported by OJS is not listed below, ask your site administrator to install the language from the site administration interface. For instructions on adding support for new languages, please consult the OJS documentation. This will be the default language for the journal site. Select all locales to support on the site via a language select menu to appear on each page. The menu will only appear if more than one locale is selected. Alternate Locale #1 Alternate Locale #2 This system optionally allows certain critical information to be entered in up to two additional languages. To use this feature, select one or two alternate locales and choose from the options listed below. Language options Title image, page header, etc. will be uploaded in each of the journal's languages. Authors should be asked to provide titles and abstracts in the other language(s), with the option of having done by journal staff. Sorry, no additional languages are available. Incomplete Upload Copyedited Version Proofreading Corrections Are you sure you want to delete this incomplete submission? View Status No submissions. Submissions to this journal are made online by following the 5 steps presented here. If you have any difficulties with this process, contact contact {$supportName} by email or phone {$supportPhone} for assistance. Journal Section Select the appropriate section for this submission (see Sections and Policies in About the Journal). Please select a section... Submission Checklist This checklist represents the requirements for items submitted to this journal, and authors must indicate, with a checkmark, that they have complied with all of them before proceeding to the next step in the submission process. You must make sure all items in the submission checklist are satisfied before continuing Comments for the Editor Enter text (optional) Please select an appropriate journal section for this submission. This journal gathers metadata about each submission, according to the standards set by the Open Archives Initiative, which is the emerging online standard for identifying research resources. This enables collective and accurate searching across OAI databases, increasing the likelihood that readers will find submissions such as this one. Editors may insist that metadata be provided before initiating the editorial process. Journal's Privacy Statement Authors For submissions with more than one author, order authors as they are to appear on citation. Reorder author's name Principal contact for editorial correspondence. Add Author Delete Author Submission Title Submission Abstract Indexing Choose terms that best describe the submission's content following the categories used by this journal, and examples provided by the editor. Separate terms with a semi-colon (term1; term2; term3). Supporting Agencies Identify agencies that provided funding or support for the work presented in this submission. Agencies Refers to geo-spatial location, chronological or historical coverage, and/or characteristics of research sample. Use the hyperlinked classification system to select classification terms and, if appropriate, numbers. Includes the study's methods or approach. English=en; French=fr; Spanish=es. Additional codes. At least one author is required. The first name, last name, and email address of each author is required. Please enter the title of your article. To upload the submission file to this journal follow these four steps...
  1. Click Browse which opens a Choose File window for locating the file on your hard drive.
  2. Locate the submission file and highlight it.
  3. Click Open on the window, which places the address in the box on this page.
  4. Click Upload on this page, which uploads the file from the computer to the journal's website and renames it following the journal's system.
  5. Once your submission has been uploaded successfully, click Continue to proceed to the next submission step.
The file can be viewed by clicking on the file name. A new or revised file can be uploaded, deleting the one that currently appears. If you have difficulties uploading the submission, contact {$supportName} by email or phone {$supportPhone} for assistance. Submission File Upload submission file No submission file uploaded. One important feature of this publishing system is its ability to post and index any number of supplementary files for each published research study, which might include (a) research instruments, (b) data sets (which comply with the terms of the study's research ethics review), and (c) sources that otherwise would be unavailable to readers. Access to these materials can improve the scholarly quality of online research by supporting a greater understanding of this study, as well as supporting replication studies and comparative work. Links to these files will appear with the published study.

The supplementary files can also be searched within the global Open Archives indexing system to which this journal adheres, while their metadata clearly identify the files' relation to the published study, as well as their ownership, etc. The supplementary files can be uploaded in any format and will not be edited or converted to other file formats, but will be made available to readers in their original format. An option will be provided to allow peer reviewers to view individual supplementary files that do not compromise the blind review process. No supplementary files have been added to this submission. Back to Supplementary Files Are you sure you want to delete this supplementary file? Add a Supplementary File Edit a Supplementary File Supplementary File Data For each supplementary file, provide the following metadata, as it pertains, and upload the file. Supplementary File Upload Creator (or owner) of file Research Instrument Research Materials Research Results Transcripts Data Analysis Data Set Source Text Brief Description Contributor or sponsoring agency Make this file available to peer reviewers.
(The supplementary file will not compromise the blind review process.) Use only with formally published materials. Date when data was collected or instrument created. Name of study or other point of origin. Specify other No file uploaded. Please enter the title of this supplementary file. Please enter a subject. Please enter a description. Review the previous steps to ensure that all of the requested information has been provided. Once satisfied, click on "Finish Submission" to submit your manuscript to {$journalTitle}. You will receive an acknowledgement by email and will be able view your document's progress through the editorial process at any time by logging in and selecting "Track Submissions." Select "Track Submissions" at any time from the main author screen to view the status of this or any other of your submissions. Help Index Contents Search Help OJS Installation Thank you for downloading the Public Knowledge Project's Open Journal Systems. Before proceeding, please read the README file included with this software. For more information about the Public Knowledge Project and our software, please visit our web site. Send bug reports or technical support inquiries about Open Journal Systems to ojs@pkp.ubc.ca, or visit our online bug reporting system.

Recommended system requirements
  • PHP >= 4.2.x
  • MySQL >= 3.23.23 or PostgreSQL >= 7.1
  • Apache >= 1.3.2x or >= 2.0.4x
  • Operating system: Linux, BSD, Solaris, Mac OS X
Other versions or platforms may work but are not supported or have not been tested. Reports of success running OJS on configurations not mentioned above are welcomed.

Changes to these settings can be made after installation by editing the file config.inc.php in the base OJS directory.

Supported database systems

OJS has currently only been tested on MySQL, although other database management systems supported by ADOdb may work (in full or partially). Compatibility reports and/or code patches for alternative DBMSs can be sent to the OJS team.

Manual installation

Select Manual Install to display the SQL statements necessary to create the OJS database schema and initial data so that database installation can be performed manually. This option is useful when debugging installation problems, particularly on unsupported platforms. Note that this installation method will not attempt to create the database or any tables, although the configuration file will still be written with the supplied database settings. Locale Settings For complete Unicode (UTF-8) support, select UTF-8 for all character set settings. Note that this support currently requires a MySQL >= 4.1.1 or PostgreSQL >= 7.1 database server. Please also note that full Unicode support requires PHP >= 4.3.0 compiled with support for the mbstring library (enabled by default in most recent PHP installations). You may experience problems using extended character sets if your server does not meet these requirements.

Your server currently supports mbstring: {$supportsMBString} The primary language to use for this system. Please consult the OJS documentation if you are interested in support for languages not listed here. Additional locales Select any additional languages to support in this system. These languages will be available for use by journals hosted on the site. Additional languages can also be installed at any time from the site administration interface. Client character set The encoding to use for data sent to and received from browsers. Connection character set The encoding to use for data sent to and received from the database. This should be the same as the client character set. Note that this capability is only supported with MySQL >= 4.1.1 or PostgreSQL >= 7.1. Select "Not available" if your database server does not meet these requirements. Database character set The encoding to use for data stored in the database. Note that this capability is only supported with MySQL >= 4.1.1 or PostgreSQL >= 7.1. Select "Not available" if your database server does not meet these requirements. Locale Locale File Settings Directory for uploads Enter full pathname to an existing directory where uploaded files are to be kept. This directory should not be directly web-accessible. Please ensure that this directory exists and is writeable prior to installation. Security Settings Password encryption algorithm SHA1 is recommended if your system supports it (requires PHP >= 4.3.0). Administrator Account This user account will become the site administrator and have complete access to the system. Database Settings Database driver Host Username Password Database name Any unsupported database drivers listed above are listed solely for academic purposes and are unlikely to work. Leave the hostname blank to connect using domain sockets instead of over TCP/IP. This is not necessary with MySQL, which will automatically use sockets if "localhost" is entered, but is required with some other database servers such as PostgreSQL. Create new database To use this option your database system must support remote database creation and your user account must have the appropriate permissions to create new databases. If installation fails with this option selected, manually create the database on your server and run the installer again with this option disabled. Install Open Journal Systems Manual Install A locale must be selected. A client character set must be selected. The directory to be used for storing uploaded files is required. The algorithm to use for encrypting user passwords must be selected. A database driver must be selected. The database name is required. Errors occurred during installation The directory specified for uploaded files does not exist or is not writeable. The public files directory does not exist or is not writeable. The installation file dbscripts/xml/install.xml does not exist or is not readable. Error parsing the database installation file {$file}. The configuration file config.inc.php does not exist or is not readable. Warning: If installation failed part way through database installation you may need to drop your OJS database or database tables before attempting to reinstall the database.
IMPORTANT!

The installer could not automatically overwrite the configuration file. Before attempting to use the system, please open config.inc.php in a suitable text editor and replace its contents with the contents of the text field below. Contents of configuration file
Manual installation

The SQL statements to create the OJS database schema and initial data are displayed below. Note that the system will be unusable until these statements have been executed manually. You will also have to manually configure the config.inc.php configuration file. SQL statements for installation Installation of OJS has completed successfully.
